loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en: Esperanza is an active entrepreneur who manages a sari-sari (variety) store business. Her previous loan from Kiva has provided working capital to expand her business and purchase more inventory for her store. With the loan, Esperanza has witnessed that her monthly income has almost doubled since she has attracted more customers with additional stock. Prior to ASHI, Esperanza had no access to capital to support her entrepreneurial dreams. Positive growth from her business has helped Esperanza finance the education of her only child. Since joining ASHI, Esperanza has experienced positive changes in her life and uses the additional income to support her third venture, vegetable and fruit vending. Esperanza hopes her businesses will continue to flourish so she can provide long-term financial stability for her family. Therefore, she is now requesting another Kiva loan, this time for 35,000 Philippine pesos, to purchase more inventory of foodstuffs for her store and more supplies of vegetables and fruits to sell. This will allow her to grow her businesses further so that her child can fulfill his dreams of completing a college degree and experience a life that’s full of contentment. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Esperanza is hopeful that her business endeavor will provide steady income and improvements in her family’s quality of life that is currently underneath an umbrella of poverty. Esperanza hopes that her businesses will expand for them so they will have savings for future use.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Khadija's Group

texts.en: Khadija lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan. Her husband runs a scrap shop in a nearby market but his earnings are not enough to fulfill the basic needs of his family, which is why Khadija started a clothes-selling business to help financially. Earlier, she sold clothes within her community but now she sells clothes in the markets. She is the mother of two daughters, both of them getting their education. Khadija has applied for a loan for the first time from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy more scrap material and enhance his business. She is hopeful that it will be a good experience for her. Her husband will be able to increase his income and provides a better standard of living for his family.

loans.use: Purchase scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn N. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 28 years old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn runs a sari-sari (variety) shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Naseem Akhtar's Group

texts.en: Naseem akhtar lives with her family in the city of Borewala, Pakistan. She is a 43-year-old housewife who spend most of her time taking care of her home and four children. One of her three sons has a mobile phone shop where he sells used handsets, and another is an electrician. The remaining two are getting their education. Naseem akhtar has applied for a loan from Asasah for her son who wants to stock a broader range of mobile phones in his shop. The mobile phone business is a profitable one in Pakistan and he not only sells them but also repairs them. Naseem hopes that by adding more choice of mobile phones in his shop he can earn more income and enhance the standard of living of her family.

loans.use: Purchase mobile phones to sell

loans.name: Sithan

texts.en: Mrs. Sithan P. is 53 years old and lives in a small village across the Mekong River, approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She has four children: one son and three daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home, and another one is a hair dresser. Her husband raises pigs at home. Sithan has been selling bread and meatballs in the local school since 2000 and also helps her husband raise pigs. She is asking for her first loan in the amount of $500 to purchase pig food.

loans.use: To purchase pig food.

loans.name: Amin

texts.en:
Amin is a 49 year old man who dedicates his time to driving a taxi and a microbus. He currently relies on two vehicles for his public transport business, one of which he drives personally, and the second he lets on lease. He has a wife and three children. Amin has about 15 years of experience in the public transportation field, and the competition is rather high in this business, since there are so many people who need it. His current request is so that he can maintain his vehicle, since this is the tool of his trade. So now, Amin is counting on your help and requesting a loan of $1500 USD. With the loan he’ll purchase the spare parts for his microbus. With your support, Amin will continue to progress. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to repair the microbus.

loans.name: Chheang

texts.en:
Mr. Chheang D., 53 (pictured above), and his wife, Mrs. Sokny Lun, 49, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 20 kilometers away. They have been married for 20 years and have four children: three sons and one daughter. The eldest son is a truck driver and the other three are in school. 

Chheang has been a motor taxi driver since 1992. He drives in Phnom Penh. His wife is a garment factory worker. Unfortunately, his motorbike is old, which costs him a lot of money to repair. Facing this problem, he is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a new motorbike. He will be able to continue his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike.

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.en:
Shuhrat works very hard, having been a farmer since childhood. Today, as a head of household, he works tirelessly to generate a stable income. He works caring for his animals, getting up very early to gather grasses so he can keep his livestock well-fed. At the same time he has a grocery store near his house. Shuhrat sells the milk they produce, as well as grocery products for his community. He is seeking this current loan for the purchase of one additional cow and foodstuffs for expanding his business. Please help support Shuhrat’s efforts so he can continue to improve his standard of living. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase a cow and foodstuffs in order to expand the business.

loans.name: Horm

texts.en:
Mr. Horm O., 33 years old (in the picture), and his wife, Mrs. Sarorn Meas, 31 years old, live in a small village outside of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2005 and have two daughters. Both of them are still young.      
 
Horm has been a construction worker for seven years. His wife is a garment factory worker. He is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Yahyojon

texts.en:
Yahyojon O. is in the livestock business. He breeds livestock, which provides sustenance for his humble home. Yahyojon is a young married man and has one child. It is important to note that since he started his business, he has acquired an abundance of experience due to his great dedication and the knowledge he has acquired breeding his animals. The reason why Yahyojon looks for support from IMON International is that he needs to purchase livestock so he may sell it and in that way, continue with his arduous work with cattle in his sector.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle in order to expand the business.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mr. Vanna K. and his wife, Mrs. Meas Uk, have been married for 20 years and have two children: one son and one daughter. The daughter is a garment factory worker and the son attends school. The family lives in suburb of Phnom Penh, about 25 kilometers away. Vanna was not available for the photo, so his wife is pictured instead.

Vanna is a driver. He drives for the ministry of health. His wife stays at home and does housework. He is applying for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for his daughter to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his daughter to drive to work.

loans.name: Rafiqan's Group

texts.en:
Rafiqan operates bangles selling business to support her family. She visits different jewelry shops in Borewala city to get orders and supplies in the given time to make an income. Her husband and son make handmade curtains (which is used for windows and doors to avoid the sun’s heat). It provides them with a reasonable income. Their business grows especially in the summer season, and they now face the problem of insufficient stock.
  
So, Rafiqan has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah to support her husband’s business. He will buy raw materials (cloth, thread and beads) needed to make more curtains. 

Rafiqan has five children, but only one is able to get an education. She wants him to complete his education and also wants to send her remaining children to school, especially her son who has started working at a young age. Rafiqan is hopeful that she will be able to fulfill her dreams of sending her children to school with the help of increased income as a result of investment.

This is a group loan.

Note: Rafiqan is showing her bangles in this photo.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making curtains.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny N. (pictured above), 39, and her husband, Mr. Sithy Chham, 40, have been married since 1989 and have five children: four sons and one daughter. Two of them are garment factory workers, one attends school, and other two are still young. Besides her children, she also has her niece, who is a tailor, living with her. They live in a small village along national road number four about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Vanny has been operating a business renting a space in her house for three years. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver for sixteen years. She is applying for her first loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to work.

loans.name: Vanary

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanary T., 29, and her husband, Mr. Phally Chhoun (pictured together), 37, have been married since 1993 and just have a young daughter. The couple lives with Vanary’s parents along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Vanary has been a garment factory worker for 8 years. Her husband has been a physician for 5 years. She is asking for a loan in the amount of $600 to build a fence around her land property.

loans.use: To build a fence around her land property.

loans.name: Sarith

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarith P. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Saret Prum, have been married since 2003 and have two children: one son and one daughter. One is in school and the other one is still young. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Two about fifteen kilometers south of Phnom Penh.

Sarith is a silk weaver. She also buys some silk fabric from other provinces far away from her house for resale in front of the garment factory. She is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase finished silk fabric for resale.

loans.use: To purchase finished silk fabric for resale.

loans.name: Ravy

texts.en:
Mrs. Ravy P. (pictured next to her pigpen) and her husband, Mr. Chanthorn Keo, have been married since 2000 and have no children yet. The family lives on an Island in Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom P., the capital city of Cambodia.

Ravy raises pigs at home. She previously had a Kiva loan, and she is now applying for another loan in the amount of $600 to purchase food for her piglets.

loans.use: To purchase food for her pigs.

loans.name: Tes

texts.en:
Tes R., 61, is married and resides with her husband and three childR. in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. R. is a housewife while her husband is a security guard, earning an income of USD 3 each per day. The three childR. are all drivers, earning an income of USD 9 per day each to help cover the family expenses.

R. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a plot of land to build a house for her family. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand the faming business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land to build a house.

loans.name: Kaniz's Group

texts.en:
Kaniz lives with her family in the city of Borewala in Pakistan. She is the mother of four children, who are getting their education. It is very difficult to afford the education expenses of the children, and that’s why Kaniz started a bangles sales business last year with the help of an Asasah loan.

Her husband has a billiard and video games shop. His shop is always busy with the presence of children. Children are the main clients of his shop. 
Kaniz has applied for a loan for the second time from Asasah for her husband’s business expansion. With the loan amount, he will buy another billiard table and video games for his game shop.

She is hopeful that this investment will increase her husband’s income sufficiently and she will be able to provide the basic necessities of life for her children.

This is a group loan.

Note: Kaniz shows her bangles in this photo.

loans.use: To purchase games for game shop.

loans.name: Yoin

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoin Y. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Chanrith Ung, have been married since 1990. They have three children: two sons and one daughter. All of them are in the local school. The family lives on an island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Yoin is a silk weaver. She buys some from her fellow villagers and than transports to sell in other provinces far away from her house such as Kampong Speu Province. Her husband is a fisherman and wooden house builder. She is requesting another loan of $300 to buy additional silk products for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional finished silk fabric for resale.

loans.name: Petronillo

texts.en:
Fifty-three year old Petronillo L. is from the town of Surallah. He is married and has 5 adult-aged children. He is involved in farming and has been planting and harvesting rice crops for more than five years already. His wife helps him sell their harvest to their town's market. A few years back, he invested in a sari-sari store where basic daily needs are sold. While he keeps his rice farm productive, his wife manages their store. 

Petronillo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Petronillo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Petronillo is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Petronillo from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies & equipment.

loans.name: Fadia

texts.en:
Fadia is a forty-eight year old widowed woman, living with her three children in Saida, Southern Lebanon. Fadia has owned a gift shop since 2004. To develop her business, she added a new product to her business, which is decorating artificiA. flowers, straw baskets, and handmade colored vases.

Fadia requested a loan from A. Majmoua, in order to buy new products such as silver trays, table decoration cloths, artificiA. flowers and home decorating accessories. She believes that as much as you give your business you will get back; her hope in her work can’t be described in words since it’s the only source to stand up and raise her little family on her own. Fadia is very talented in her business and seeks new opportunities all the time.

loans.use: To buy new products for her business.

loans.name: Nun

texts.en: Mrs. Nun M. is a villager in Andoung Kien village in Takeo province and she is 56-year-old. She is a farmer who owns three-hectare of land to cultivate rice to cultivate rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Rum Nos, is a village chief and he is also own a plow machine in which it can rent to farmers to plow. Her problem is that her field is far away from irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Nun M. is seeking for a loan to buy gasoline. She is a mother of two children whom all are studying at local school. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy gasoline

loans.name: Muth

texts.en: Muth P., 29, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. P. grows vegetables to sell, earning an income of USD 1 per day. Her husband is employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 2 each per day. P. is requesting a loan of USD 100 to purchase vegetable seeds to expand her farming. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. P.'s husband appears in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy vegetable seeds.

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: In Serei Duoch village in Takeo province has a person, Mrs. Chorn T. was born in 1946. She is a farmer who owns two-hectare plot land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Son Svay, is a village chief who gets low salary to support his family. This day she has some problem because her field is infertile soil. So to improve her face production, Mrs. Chorn T. is seeking for a loan to buy fertilizer and rest of the loan she buys forty chickens. Through this activity they support four children, one of whom is a chauffeur, another is a security guard, while the other one is a construction worker, and the other is attending in local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Eoun

texts.en:
Eoun O., 42, is widowed and resides with three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products.

O. is a fisher and sells her fish for an income of USD 5.30 per day. Two of her children are employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 120 each per month to help cover the family expenses. O. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to repair the house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to open a hair dressing shop for her daughter. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To repair the house.

loans.name: Sris

texts.en: Mrs. Sris C., who lives in Andoung Kien village in Takeo province, is 27 years old. She is a gasoline seller at her home while her husband, Mr. is a farmer who owns two-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family moreover he owns a pump machine for rent to farmers. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve production, Mrs. Sris C. is seeking for a loan to buy more gasoline to resale. She is a mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy more gasoline to resale

loans.name: Noy

texts.en: Noy L., 34, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. L. sews traditional fabrics at home, earning an income of USD 3.50 per day. Her husband is a farmer growing vegetables and earns an income of USD 3 each per day. L. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase a plot of farmland to improve the farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland.

loans.name: Yim

texts.en: Mrs. Yim S. lives in Ta Poun Lech village in Takeo province and she is 52 years old. She is a broom seller door to door moreover she is also a pig breeder. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve her breeding pig, Mrs. Yim S. is requesting for a loan to buy four piglets and pig food for breeding to increase income this current year. Her husband, Mr. Vorn Yen, is a farmer who owns one point five-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is a construction worker, while the others are studying in local public school. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy four piglets and pig food for breeding

loans.name: Srieng

texts.en: Mrs. Srieng B. was born in 1965 and she lives in Dak Por village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. She is widow with two children, one of whom is a laborer of construction road, and the other is housework. Although they all try to work hard they can earn less income. So to improve her condition her family living, Mrs. Srieng B. is seeking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business to increase her family’s income this current year with this loan.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en: Mrs. Phalla P., who lives in Trapeang Chhuk village in Takeo province, is 51-year-old. She is a floor mat seller door-to-door where she can earn some money to support her family. She is widow with four children, one of whom is a shoes seller, while the other one is a shoemaker, and the others are attending in local public school. Her problem is that her children have work place far away from her home. So to solve this problem, Mrs. Phalla P. is asking for a loan to buy a new motorbike for transportation.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for transportation

loans.name: Seom

texts.en: Seom N., 31, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. N. raises pigs at home, earning an income of USD 1 per day. Her husband is a farmer, growing rice for an income of USD 3 each per day. N. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a plot of farmland to improve the farming business. In the future, she would like to use aN. additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland.

loans.name: Khen

texts.en:
Khen E., 39, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorea Temples. E. is a farmer, earning an income of $3 US per day. Her husband raises pigs and also earns an income of $3 per day. 

E. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase fertilizer for her rice field and animal medicine for the pigs. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buying fertilizer and pig medicine

loans.name: Saraem

texts.en: Mrs. Saraem S. is a villager in Kampeaeng Tboung village in Takeo province. She was born in 1971 who owns a general store in local village where she can earn a large profit from it. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve her face business, Mrs. Saraem S. is applying for a loan to buy more groceries, gasoline, fertilizer, and rice to resale. Her husband, Mr. Vy Orn, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. This couple has two children whom all are studying in local public school. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy more groceries, gasoline, fertilizer, and rice to resale

loans.name: Nheb

texts.en: Nheb S., 31, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorea Temples. S. and her husband are farmers, earning an income of $1.50 US each per day. S. is requesting a loan of $350 to purchase rice grain to produce pig food to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buying rice grain

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn J. is a married woman who lives in Poblacion Taloot, Sibonga, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: an Internet cafe, a general store, and a fishing business.Her husband Elmer J., who is 50 years old, works as a seaman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 4 children who are 20 to 25 years old. 

Evelyn  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Evelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of 12,000 PHP, bettering the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her sixth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use as additional capital to purchase another computer so that she can continue to save up for the future of her children. Evelyn J. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: buying a computer

loans.name: Seak

texts.en:
Seak Y., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorea Temples. Y. is a farmer, earning an income of $0.50 US per day. Her husband is a farmer and a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of $2.50 US per day. 

Y. is requesting a loan of $250 US to purchase pigs to raise. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy pigs

loans.name: Somaly

texts.en: In Kampeaeng Tboung village in Takeo province has a person, Mrs. Somaly R. was born in 1965. She owns a general store in local village where she can earn a large profit to support her family while her husband, Mr. Yun Vorng, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. They all try to work hard but they can earn less income. So to improve her family living, Mrs. Somaly R. is seeking for a loan to buy some piglets, pig food for breeding to start a new business and rest of the loan she buys more groceries to resale, fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are seamstresses in garment factory, while the other is studying in school. Her husband is taken the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy some piglets, pig food for breeding to start a new business

loans.name: Deng

texts.en:
Dang T., 37, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorea Temples. T. is a farmer and raises pigs at home, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband (who appears in the photograph) is a farmer, growing rice for an income of $3 US per day. One of her children is a car repairman. 

T. is requesting a loan of $12,00 US to purchase car glass to expand her son’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy car glass to expand the son's business

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem C., 35, is widowed and resides with her mother and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorea Temples. C. sells groceries, earning an income of $2.50 US per day. Her mother is a farmer growing rice and earns an income of $2 per day.

C. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a plot of farmland to improve the farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Saroeun's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four members who have been selected Mrs. Saroeun P. is a group leader who is 34-year-old located in Veay Chhneah village in Takeo province. All the members will use portion of their loan for different purposes. Mrs. Saroeun P. is a weaver at her home where she can earn money to support her family while her husband, Mr. Pou K., is a motorbike taxi driver. Her problem is that her husband’s motorbike is too old to use, but she has a little money to buy. So to solve this problem, Mrs. Saroeun P. is finding for a loan to add more money to purchase a new motorbike to instead the old one. She is a mother of two children whom all are studying in local school.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em E., 53, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. E. sells Chinese noodles and porridge, earning an income of $5 US per day. Her husband is a barber and earns an income of $2 per day. 

E. is requesting a loan of $1000 US to purchase a motorbike for a child to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Nerla

texts.en:
Nerla C. is from the town of Surallah. She is married and has five adult children. Nerla owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Nerla has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

Nerla joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Nerla has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Nerla is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Nerla from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Han

texts.en: Han T., 40, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. T. sells green coconuts, earning an income of $6 US per day. Her husband is a carpenter and earns an income of $3 per day. T. is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase coconuts and to repair the house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her current business.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more coconuts; repair the house

loans.name: Lem

texts.en: Lem K., 29, is married and resides with his wife (who appears in the photograph) and two children in Battambong Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality rice products. K. is a construction worker, earning an income of $2.70 per day. His wife is a fish seller and earns an income of $5 per day. K. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more fish to resell and a plot of farmland. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to expand his current business.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy fish and a plot of farmland

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
Hazel L. is from the town of Surallah. She is 36 years old. Hazel is single. Hazel owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She also manages a farm where she plants and harvests rice crops. Hazel has been engaged in her business for over five years.

Hazel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Hazel has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Hazel is requesting a new loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell  and also for farm inputs for her rice farm. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Hazel from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing livestock to raise & sell; inputs for rice farm

loans.name: Ty's Group

texts.en: In Prey Lvea Lech village in Takeo province has four members whom all are made up a group loan. Mrs. Ty H. is a group leader who is 45 years old, selected by the other members will use portion of their loan for varied ways. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Kea Khlork, is a construction worker. Her problem is that her field is infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Ty H. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and rest of the loan she hires plow machine to plow her field. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a seamstress in garment factory, while the others are attending in local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Nhem S., 58, is widowed and resides with her three children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known as the most populated area in the country. S. sells Cambodian traditional cakes, earning an income of USD 2 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for one of the children to commute to work.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to expand her current farming business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Thoang

texts.en:
Thoang L., 59, is widowed and resides with her three children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known as the most populated area in the country.

L. is a hair dresser, earning an income of USD 2 per day. L. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase more hairdressing tools to improve her current business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more hairdressing tools.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 47 years old. She is a widowed mother of 8 children between the ages of 10 and 24. Six of the children are currently attending school. She has been farming for 20 years in the outskirts of Kitale town in Western Kenya. Her main product is milk, maize and beans which she sells locally. She also earns income from her rental houses in the same area.

Jane has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES.41,600 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that with this loan, she will be able to acquire another asset and meet the basic needs of the family with the extra income from the sale of milk.

In future, she hopes to acquire a good dairy cow that will increase the production of milk and earn her more income. She is grateful to Juhudi for increasing her sources of income generating activities.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran lives in a small house in a city called Borewala city which is located in Punjab, Pakistan. Her husband works for the police department. Her son is a driver by trade. He drives a tractor in fields. He also uses his tractor to deliver the items, such as crops and flour sacks, to designated places. 
To support her family financially, Sugran makes and sells stools (made by wooden sticks and leather seats by using soft foam for sitting). She has been doing this work for over five years. Her income helps to support the urgent needs of the family.

She has applied for a loan for the 2nd time from Asasah for her son. With the loan amount he will repair his tractor and continue his work. She is hopeful that with a fully repaired tractor, her son will be able to continue his work for a longer period of time and make more income. She is collecting money to marry off her daughter, and she hopes that with the help of increased income she will be able to marry off her daughter soon.

loans.use: To repair a tractor.

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Prak L., 59, is married and resides with his wife in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, an area known as the most populated area in the country. L. is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 12 per day. His wife sells porridge for an income of USD 9 per day.

L. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike to operate his business efficiently. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike.

loans.name: Hernane

texts.en:
Hernane D. C. is from the town of Surallah. He is 51 years old. Hernane is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Hernane owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. He also tills a farm where rice crops are planted and harvested. Hernane has been engaged in his business for over 3 years.

Hernane joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hernane has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Hernane is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Hernane from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Charity

texts.en:
Charity has been farming for the last 20 years in Nkubu town in Eastern Kenya. She has employed one farm-hand. She sells her coffee, bananas and milk to the local market.

Charity is 50 years old. She is a widowed mother of 7 children between the ages of 15 and 32. Her youngest child is still attending school.

Charity recently completed her previous loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES.30,000 and has requested this loan of KES.60,000 to expand her poultry project. She says that the extra income from this loan will help in educating her child and grandchildren in school.

Her major challenge has been insufficient funds to expand her activities, and pest and diseases which attack her crops and animals.

She says that Juhudi Kilimo loans are flexible in terms of repayment, since they give grace periods during the loan term.

loans.use: To expand her poultry project.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store.

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick is 58 years old. He is married and has been blessed with 6 children between the ages of 12 and 30. Four of his children are attending school.

He is a farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya, where he has been farming for 20 years. He has two employees and he sells his milk, vegetables, maize, cassava, millet and fish to the local market. He solely depends on the income from his farming activities to cater for the family's needs. His biggest challenge has been the high cost of dairy feed which makes it hard to break even.

Fredrick has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES.62,400 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. With this loan, he will be able to increase his milk production and this will earn him more income that will enable him cater for the family's needs. 

He hopes to acquire another dairy cow that will increase his milk production in future. He is grateful to Juhudi for uplifting his economic standards.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Abdramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abdramane  T.  est âgé de 35 ans marié et père de quatre enfants. Il est domicilié à Banconi–Koulikoro, avec ses deux épouses et ses enfants, dans un des quartiers de la ville de  Sikasso.
Abdramane T. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initié à cette activité de stockage et commercialisation des céréales (maïs, mil, sorgho) depuis maintenant  plus de sept  ans. Il dispose de son magasin à Kaboïla I en face de la Clinique Guinso. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis l’année 2009. Il a bénéficié d’un premier  prêt qui fut correctement remboursé.
Il sollicite ce deuxième prêt pour acheter, 28 sacs de Maïs et 30 sacs de Mil en provenance des localités environnantes de Sikasso. 
Ces marchandises sont d’abord stockées dans son magasin avant d’être revendues en gros à une clientèle composée des détaillants et de chefs de famille.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 180 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdramane T. is 35 years old, married, and the father of four children. He is domiciled in Banconi–Koulikoro with his two wives and his children in a district of Sikasso City. After having run many businesses without success, he got started in the business of storing and marketing grains (corn, millet, and sorghum) seven years ago. He has a store in Kaboïla I, opposite the Guinso Clinic. Concerned about further satisfying his burgeoning customer base, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in 2009. He has had an initial loan, which was properly repaid. He is requesting a second loan to buy 28 sacks of corn, and 30 sacks of millet from towns surrounding Sikasso. These goods are first stocked up in his store and are then resold in bulk to a customer base composed of retailers and heads-of-household. With this loan, he envisions making a monthly profit of 180,000 francs CFA. The profits will be used essentially for helping to cover family expenses and to pay the loan interest. The rest will be invested in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying grains

loans.name: Ploak

texts.en:
Ploak S., 37, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. S. sells food at a local market, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Her husband is a construction foreman and earns an income of USD 8 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 900 to purchase more construction supplies to improve her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy more construction supplies.

loans.name: Sugran's Group

texts.en:
Sugran lives in a city called Borewala in Pakistan which is a small city of Punjab Pakistan. She is the mother two children: a son and a daughter. Her husband sells timbers and her son works in a water pipe manufacturing factory. 

She herself stays at home, manages the household chores, and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and mother. Her daughter also helps her with the household work.
  
She has applied for a loan for the 2nd time from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy timbers in bulk to sell. She is hopeful that with the investment in her husband’s business, he will be able to increase his income, which will help her in saving money for her daughter’s marriage. 
Sugran has maintained her good credit behavior with last year's loan and attended all the meetings as a responsible client.

loans.use: To purchase timbers for selling.

loans.name: Soam

texts.en:
Soam P., 43, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. P. sells beverages, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a taxi driver and earns an income of USD 6 per day. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase more beverages to resell.

In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more beverages to resell.

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
Âgé de plus de  51 ans, Monsieur  Salif Y., polygame et père de sept  enfants, réside avec ses deux femmes et ses enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école et après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, il s’est vite initié aux activités commerciales notamment l’achat-vente des appareils électroniques (radios, cassette (K7), panneau Satellitaires, Batteries, Antennes Paraboliques, téléphones portables et divers) il y a maintenant plus de 26 ans. 
Fort de cette expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes. 
Ainsi, il sollicite ce quatrième prêt  qui lui permettra d’acheter,10 radios de marques différentes, 15 téléphones portables de marques différentes et accessoires, 4 panneaux satellitaires, 3 batteries blindées, 7 antennes paraboliques et 100 cassettes afin de pouvoir satisfaire à la demande de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroitre. 
Il achète ses marchandises à Bamako qui seront vendues dans sa boutique située au pleine cœur de la gare routière à côté de la compagnie Kènèdougou Voyage à Sikasso . Ses ventes se font au comptant comme à crédit.
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 270 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices, il compte résoudre les dépenses de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Over 51 years of age, Mr. Salif Y., a polygamist and the father of seven children, lives with his two wives and his children in Sanoubougou I, one of the working-class districts in the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mali). Not having had a chance to go to school and having tried various lines of business without success, some 26 years ago he has launched a business trading electronic appliances (radios, tape recorders, satellite dishes, batteries, dish antennas, cellular phones and other miscellaneous items). Now he has plenty of experience, enjoys a good reputation in the business and receives many orders. And thus he is seeking a fourth loan, which will allow him to purchase 10 radio sets of various brands, 15 cellular phones and accessories, 4 satellite dishes, 3 armor-plated batteries, 7 dish antennas and 100 tapes in order to satisfy continuously growing customer demand. He stocks up in Bamako and sells his wares in his store located very centrally in a bus station in Sikasso, next to the Kènèdougou Voyage travel agency. He sells for cash as well as in credit. With this loan, he plans to achieve a monthly income of 270,000 West African Francs. He plans to use the income to cover family expenses, pay the interest on his loan and reinvest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various electronics [for resale]

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac has been operating his mixed farm in Kitale town in Western Kenya for 10 years. He has employed two people from his community to help with the farm work.

Isaac is 28 years old and married with 4 children between the ages of 1½ and 12. Three of his children are currently attending school. Isaac is also a mechanic (pictured on his motorbike and onlooking is one of his children).

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES.80,000 to start a poultry project and build a dairy unit. He says that he hopes the extra income from this loan will enable him to meet the basic needs of the family. He would also like to expand and increase his productivity in terms of the number of chickens and also practice zero grazing.

His primary challenge has been the fluctuation in the prices of milk and poultry diseases.

loans.use: To start a poultry project and build a dairy unit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his poultry project.

loans.name: Oun

texts.en:
Oun N., 29, is single and resides with his mother in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. N. is a tuk-tuk driver, earning an income of USD 4.50 per day. His mother is a Cambodian noodle seller and earns an income of USD 2 per day.

N. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a new motorbike to operate his business more efficiently. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. N.'s wife appears in the photograph because N. is not available.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Bwagoga Eco Bakyara Tukwatanise, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Gladys K. is a hard working business lady. The 46 year old married mother of 6 school going children sweats her guts out selling agro produce like maize, sorghum, millet, beans, peas, ground nuts in a small rural area of Bisheshe, Ibanda. She has been doing this business for the last 6 years, which she started with her little capital from banana sales. She gets many customers who buy her products for food consumption.

She is able to make 80,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. This is a fair earning by any standards, but she requires a loan that will help her buy more food supplies for the business. Then she will be able to meet the customers' demand and also get more revenue. She belongs to a group of members and they insure each other in paying back the loan.

In order to start her business, she received capital from her banana plantation and it is because of hard work that she was able to get where she is right now.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for the business.

loans.name: Chhourn

texts.en:
Chhourn T., 45, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. T. sells fish, earning a gross income of USD 38 per day. Her husband is a farmer and earns an income of USD 1 per day.

T. is requesting a loan of USD 200 to purchase more fish to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell.

loans.name: Beverly

texts.en:
Beverly D. C. is from the town of Surallah. She is 38 years old. Beverly is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Beverly owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Beverly has been engaged in her business for over 12 years.

Beverly joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beverly has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Beverly is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Beverly from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Bakary

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Bakary B.  est âgé de plus de 47 ans, polygame et père de huit. Il vit avec ses deux femmes et ses enfants à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, il s’est vite initié aux activités de commercialisation des engrais, pesticides et insecticides depuis plus de vingt ans. Avec une telle expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes, mais les ressources nécessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins fait défaut. 
Ainsi, il sollicite ce troisième prêt, auprès de Soro Yiriwaso, qui lui permettra d’acheter, 9 sacs d’urées, 8 sacs de complexe coton et 8 sacs de complexe maïs et quelques pulvérisateurs, afin de pouvoir satisfaire à la demande de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroitre. Tous les deux prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Il s’approvisionne auprès du représentant de TOGUINA (une usine de fabrique d’engrais) à Sikasso dans son magasin au nouveau marché de Médine Sikasso. Avec une clientèle composée des agriculteurs certains de ses clients payent au comptant, d’autre à crédit.
 Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Bakary B. is over 47 years old and is the polygamous father of eight. He lives with his two wives and his children in Hamdallaye, one of the more sought after neighbourhoods of the city of Sikasso (in the Third Administrative District of the Republic of Mali). He wasn't fortunate enough to go to school, but he quickly learned how to market fertilizers, pesticides and insecticides and has been in this business for more than twenty years. Because of his extensive experience in this business, he has a good reputation and many orders, but doesn't have the resources necessary to satisfy the demand. Therefore he is seeking a third loan from Soro Yiriwaso, which will allow him to buy 9 bags of urea, 8 bags of cotton fertilizer blend and 8 bags of maïze fertilizer blend as well as some sprayers, so that he can satisfy the needs of his ever growing client base. Both previous loans were reimbursed on time. He buys his supplies from the representative of the Toguina fertilizer factory in Sikasso, who has a store in the new Medina market in Sikasso. His clients are farmers and some pay by cash while others have lines of credit. With this loan, Mr. B. expects to make 150,000 CFA francs per month. This income will allow him to cover his and his family's living expenses, pay interest on the loan, and invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides, insecticides and sprayers

loans.name: Guljamila

texts.en:
Guljamila D. is 58 years old. She lives in Bakai-Ata village, in the heart of Kyrgyzstan, with her family. She has four children; two daughters are married and live with their own families, her elder son lives in Bishkek (the capital of Kyrgyzstan), and her younger son lives with Guljamila and helps his parents in farming. Guljamila graduated as an accountant and worked in a local market, where she earned a reputation as a punctual, hard working and thrifty woman.

In 2001, however, starting with an initial capital of 30'000 Kyrgyz Soms, Guljamila's family began to cultivate land and grow apple and plum trees. In addition, they started breeding cows, which allowed them earnings from selling the milk. Her husband helps Guljamila in farming and selling their products.

Guljamila will use her loan of 135'000 Kyrgyz Soms to broaden her business by buying four cows, fertilizer for her apple and plum gardens, as well as to rent a plot of land to cultivate beans. This will allow her a better harvest next year. Also, she plans to construct a winter barn for her cattle. With the revenues from these investments she will be able to raise her family's living standards.

In the future, Guljamila plans to further augment the number of cattle. To better control the ongoing expansion of her farm, she plans to buy a computer to implement an electronical system of accounting. She also would like to acquire a drying machine to process her apples and plums and the ones of other farmers. The revenues from the current loan will help her achieve these goals.

Bai-Tushum's Kiva borrowers benefit from a 5% discount on the interest rate if they pay back without delay.
 
Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle and to cultivate land.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en:
Phan H., 43, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. H. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 1 per day. Her husband is a construction worker and earns an income of USD 3.50 per day.

H. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase cows to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. H.'s husband appears in the photograph because H. is not available.

loans.use: To buy cows.

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Né le 04 Mai 1964 à Sikasso, Monsieur Daouda  B. est polygame avec deux épouses et quatre enfants. Il réside avec sa famille dans la grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Mancourani I, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après plusieurs années dans le métier du chauffeur, il décida il y a maintenant quatre ans de revenir  au métier familial qui est le métier de forgeron. 
Il achète des ferrailles pour en faire différentes objets (Charrues, Semoirs, Charrettes, Dabas, Marmites, etc.) qui seront vendus dans les marchés hebdomadaires des localités environnantes de Sikasso (N’Tchongobougou, Kadiolo et Hérémakono) au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
Il est beaucoup sollicité et les commandes de ses clients ne cessent d’augmenter. 
Afin de satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier  prêt qui lui permettra d’acheter, une tonne de ferraille.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt, un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de roulement, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on May 4, 1964 at Sikasso, Mr. Daouda B. is polygamous, with two wives and four children. He lives with his family in a large traditional extended family in Mancourani I, the city center of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After working for several years as a driver, he decided four years ago to return to blacksmithing, the family trade. He pays in cash and often by credit for scrap iron to make various objects (ploughs, drills, carts, axes, cooking pots, etc.) which are sold in the weekly markets of Sikasso’s surrounding areas (N’Tchongobougou, Kadiolo, and Hérémakono). He is much sought after and the orders from his clients keep growing. In order to satisify this ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is his first loan request which will enable him to buy a ton of scrap iron. With this loan, he expects to earn an average monthly profit of 150,000 CFA which will be used principally to increase his working capital, contribute to the family’s expenses and pay the interest on his loan.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy scrap iron

loans.name: Muth

texts.en:
Muth C., 22, is married and lives with her husband and a child in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. C. is a housewife while her husband is an electrician, earning an income of USD 8 per day.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 200 to purchase piglets to raise for sale. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.

Joice is 49 years old and is widowed. She has seven children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Madame Salimata S. a plus de 34 ans, mariée, elle réside avec son époux et ses quatre enfants à Banconi, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Salimata S. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité de stockage et commercialisation des  céréales (maïs, mil, sorgho, etc.) depuis plus de sept  ans. Elle dispose son magasin à Kaboïla I en face de la B.O.A. (Banque Ouest Africaine). 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ six  ans. 
Après 5 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association Kotognogontala de Banconi), et elle est actuellement à son 6 ème prêt individuel, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 23 sacs de Maïs, 10 sacs de Sorgho et 11 sacs de Mil. Elle s’approvisionne dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso avant de les revendre en  demi-gros et en détail, à une clientèle composée généralement des chefs de famille.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Salimata S. is over 34 years old and married. She lives with her husband and her four children in Banconi, a neighborhood on the outskirts of the city of Sikasso (in the Third Adminstrative District of the Republic of Mali), Mrs. S. started her business of warehousing and selling grains (maïze, millet, sorghum, etc.) after she unsuccessfully tried a number of other businesses. She has been running her current business for more than seven years. Her store is in Kaboïla, across from the West African Bank (B.O.A.). In order to better satisfy the needs of her ever growing client base, she decided to join Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance about six years ago. She has participated in five group loans with a neighborhood women's group (the Kotognogontala Association of Banconi), and is now on her sixth individual loan; all the previous loans have been repaid on time. With this loan, Mrs. S. plans to buy 23 bags of maïze, 10 bags of sorghum and 11 bags of millet. She buys her stock in the outskirts of Sikasso before re-selling it at discount wholesale or retail prices to clients who are usually heads of households. She hopes to earn 200,000 francs per month in income that will be used to finance her business, contribute to the family's expenses and pay interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grains

loans.name: Mrs. Nhar Ith Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has eighteen people who live in Prey Kduoch village in Takeo province. Mrs. Nhar I. is a village bank president who is 63 years old, selected by the other members who will use portion of their loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. Chork Gnem, are farmers who own one-hectare plot land to cultivate rice to support their family living and he is also a rickshaw. Now she has some problem because her field is infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Nhar I. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and rest of the loan she wants to buy a sewing machine to start a new business for her children. She is a mother of two children whom all are seamstresses in garment factory and they are also learning sewing. All the members are shown in the picture but some of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Dourng

texts.en:
Dourng S., 51, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. S. sells porridge and noodles, earning an income of USD 6 per day. Her husband is a gardener at a hotel and earns an income of USD 4 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to expand her food business and to repair her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support her children’s study. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To expand her food business and repair her house

loans.name: Romie Julie

texts.en: Romie Julie L. is from the town of Surallah. He is 39 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Romie Julie owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. From his income, he was able to open a sari-sari (variety) store that his wife manages. They sell stuff like shampoo, soft drinks and many other items. He hopes that his store will improve. Romie Julie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Romie Julie is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seed, fertilizer, and other farm inputs. This loan will be his fourth from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame Fatoumata K. est âgée de 42 ans, mariée et mère de quatre enfants. Elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I-Kapel Kourou, un des quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Fatoumata K. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et vente des condiments alimentaires (oignons, cube magie, moutarde, etc.) depuis plus de dix ans. 
Elle mène son activité dans son quartier, au bord de la route allant à Zignasso (village situé à environ 15km de la ville de Sikasso) où elle dispose  d’une boutique. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans. 
Après 3 prêts solidaires dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association BENKADI de Sanoubougou I), tous correctement remboursés, elle est actuellement à son premier prêt individuel.
 Elle compte acheter avec ce premier prêt,individuel, 1 bidons d’huile alimentaire, 3 paquets de cube magie, 1 sac d’oignon, 3 paquets de moutarde, etc. 
Elle  achète ses marchandises au grand marché de Sikasso pour ensuite les revendre en détail, au comptant et à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts du  prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata K. is 42 years old, married and the mother of four children. She lives with her husband and their children in Sanoubougou I-Kapel Kourou, one of the peripheral districts in the town of Sikasso (the third administrative region of Mal).
