After trying many activities without success, she got engaged in selling food condiments (onions, Maggie bouillon cubes, mustard etc) and has been in this line of business for over ten years now. She sells locally, near the road leading to Zignasso, a village located about 15 km from the town of Sikasso, where she keeps a store. The quality of her goods makes her store very popular with the customers. In order to satisfy the demand of her ever growing customer base, two years ago she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After three solidarity loans through the local women’s association (Association Benkadi of Sanoubougou I), all properly repaid, she is now on her first individual loan. With this first individual loan, she plans to purchase one can of vegetable oil, three packs of Maggie cubes, one bag of onions, three bags of mustard etc. She stocks up at the big market of Sikasso and later retails the goods for cash or on credit. With this loan, she plans to achieve monthly revenue of 80,000 West African Francs, which will essentially be used towards covering family expenses and paying the interest on her loan, with the remainder reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing food condiments

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 68 years old and is a farmer from the town of Murang'a in Central Province, Kenya. He has been farming for twelve years and employs two farm-hands. His main products are maize and beans which he sells to the local market.

Michael also receives income from his pension, from rental houses and from his quarry services to the locals. His biggest challenge has been lack of enough capital to expand his businesses.

Michael has requested this second loan of KES 65,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase three dairy goats and to build a dairy unit. He says that, with this loan, his family income will increase because of the expansion in his dairy business.

Michael would like to expand his dairy business by purchasing several pedigree goats and by building more rental houses. He says that Juhudi, unlike other financial institutions, is really helping farmers of small farms.

loans.use: To purchase three dairy goats and to build a dairy unit

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn S., 31, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the favorite tourist place in the country.

S. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a construction worker and earns an income of USD 8 per day. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more construction tools to improve her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more construction tools for her husband's business

loans.name: Han

texts.en:
Han H., 50, is married and lives with her husband and five children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for being the favorite tourist place in the country. H. and her husband are farmers and also raise pigs, earning an income of USD 3 each per day.

H. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to use for commuting

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen K. is currently in the business of selling both dried and fresh fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more fish and some tomatoes to sell.

Hellen is 41 years old and is married to a director. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

loans.use: To stock more fish and some tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Djénéba

texts.fr:
Madame Djénéba  S. est âgée  de 62 ans. Elle vit avec son mari et ses 6 enfants au  quartier Pelengana Sébénikoro de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à  l’école par refus de ses parents qui voyaient à l’école une porte de déperdition des filles, elle commença tôt les activités génératrices de revenus. Elle mena plusieurs petites activités, vente de beignets, de chaussures, de mil et d’arachide grillé. Finalement elle opte pour cette dernière activité (la vente de mil et d’arachide grillé) qu’elle exerce depuis 12 ans au marché château de Ségou et dans les différents marchés  de  foires (lundi de Ségou et jeudi de Banankoro). 
Pour griller l’arachide elle pose un poêle sablonneux  contenant de l’arachide  sur le feu, de temps en temps elle remue la contenance à l’aide d’une louche, cette opération répétitive peut prendre quelques moments.
Dans le dessein de renforcer son activité, elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 56 mois. Après 4 prêts solidaires et 4 prêts individuels tous  bien remboursés, elle est à son 5ème prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser  pour acheter,  18 sacs d’arachide et 12 sacs de mil. Elle s’approvisionne en arachide à Ségou et mil à Banankoro.
Madame Djénéba  S. vend  au comptant à  une clientèle composée d’hommes et  de femmes. 
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 FCFA, ce qui  lui permettra de faire face aux dépenses familiales et participer à des événements sociaux (mariage, baptême et funérailles).
texts.en:
Mrs. Djénéba S. is 62 years old. She lives with her husband and their six children in the Pelengana Sébénikoro district of Ségou (the third administrative region of Mali). She did not have an opportunity to go to school as her parents, who saw school as the road to perdition for girls, had refused to allow it. Therefore she started working and earning an income early on. She tried different types of activities, such as selling beignets, shoes, millet and grilled peanuts. Finally, she settled on this last line of business (selling millet and grilled peanuts), which she has been engaged in for about 12 years, at the Château de Segou market as well as other local markets (the Monday market in Ségou and the Thursday market of Banankoro). In order to grill peanuts , she puts them in a large heavy skillet over fire. From time to time she stirs peanuts with a ladle; this repetitive process can take a while With the goal of strengthening her business, she turned to Soro Yiriwaso. She has been a member for 56 months. After four solidarity loans and four individual loans, all duly repaid, she is now on her fifth individual loan, which she plans to use for purchasing 18 bags of peanuts and 12 bags of millet. She stocks up on peanuts in Ségou and on millet in Banankoro. Mrs. Djénéba S. sells for cash to a customer base composed of both men and women. She plans to earn a monthly revenue of 70,000 West African Francs, which will allow her to meet some family expenses and participate in social events such as weddings, baptisms and funerals.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing peanuts and millet

loans.name: Cheuy

texts.en:
Cheuy C., 26, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known to be the favorite tourist place in the country.

C. produces traditional cake, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a chef and also earns an income of USD 3 per day. C. appears in the photograph with her husband.

C. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Mrs. Nuon Saing Villlage Bank Group

texts.en: Fifteen people, who live in Prey Kduoch village in Takeo province, are made up a village bank loan. Mrs. Nuon S. is a village bank president who is 51 years old. She is a farmer who owns one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family and a side this she is also a clothes seller. Since her business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve this business, Mrs. Nuon S. is seeking for a loan to bU. more clothes to resale. She is widow with two children, one of whom is a seamstress in garment factory, while the other is attending in local public school. Mrs. La Chem is a group guarantor so she is presented in the picture. All the members are shown in the picture but one of them are blocked.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resale

loans.name: Ma

texts.en:
Ma P., 36, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for being the favorite tourist place in the country.

P. and her husband are farmers and recyclers, earning an income of USD 5 each per day. P.'s husband appears in the photograph because P. was not available.

P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase fertilizer to improve their farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to improve their farm

loans.name: Zaweria

texts.en:
Zaweria is 50 years old and is married with seven children who are all adults. Three of her children are currently in college.

Zaweria is a farmer from the town of Murang'a in Central Province, Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for thirty-three years, producing maize and milk which she sells to the local market. She also depends on the income of her husband who is employed.

Zaweria has requested this loan of KES 53,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says that this loan will enable her to purchase a good dairy cow that will produce enough milk to sell, which will earn her income that will help improve her family’s living standard.

In the future, Zaweria would like to acquire four more dairy cows, each producing twenty liters daily. She says that farmers cannot afford to raise such an amount of money on their own but, through Juhudi, farmers can afford to realize their dreams.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Expédit Athanase

texts.fr: Né en 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, D. Expédit Athanase est marié à SEWA Hermione, une ménagère. Le couple a quatre enfants à charge, dont trois représentent leurs enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Il y a environs sept ans que Expédit s'est installé à PK10 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, où il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants. Expédit s'implique beaucoup plus dans les diverses charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Expédit n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire, mais a appris la coiffure. Depuis cinq ans, Expédit mène cette activité qui lui permet de nourrir sa famille et d'assurer ses propres besoins. De façon secondaire, Expédit vend des cartes de recharges téléphoniques dans son atelier situé à PK10. C'est la première fois que Expédit sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue d'équiper son salon de coiffure de matériels de coiffure plus adaptés à son activité.
texts.en:
Born in 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Mr. D. Expédit Athanase is married to Ms. SEWA Hermione, a housewife. The couple have four children, of whom three are their own. All of the children are in school. About seven years ago, Expédit settled in PK10, in the Commune of Sèmè-Podji, where she lives with his wife and children. He is involved a lot more in the various family expenses. Expédit attended primary school only, but he has learned how to cut hair. For five years, he has been running this business, which enables him to feed his family and to support himself. Secondarily, he sells phone recharge cards in his shop located in PK10. This is the first time that Expédit has requested a loan from ALIDé with the goal of supplying his shop with equipment better suited to his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying hair clippers and wheel chairs

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Van K., 30, is married and lives with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for being the favorite tourist place in the country.

K. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 3 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and earns an income of USD 6 per day. K.’s husband appears in the photograph because K. was not available.

K. is requesting a loan of USD 1,200 to purchase a tuk-tuk (a motorcycle-based taxi) for her husband to expand his business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a tuk-tuk for her husband's business

loans.name: Baraka Group

texts.fr:
Pascasie N. est une commerçante âgée de 38ans qui habite la Commune urbaine de Buyenzi en mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de pagnes pour dames depuis 23 ans dans la ville de Bujumbura. Elle a toujours exerce le métier de  commerce. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 5e année primaire. C’est une veuve. Elle arrive au 7e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère de 5enfants  âgés de 16ans, 14 ans, 10 ans, 8ans et de 6ans. Tous ses enfants étudient. 

Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter la quantité de pagnes qu’elle achète pour revendre aux clients. Elle espère diversifier son commerce dans l’avenir en incluant les articles ménagers comme les assiettes. Elle a l’espoir qu’avec le crédit de Turame, elle  sera à mesure de supporter les frais de scolarité de ses enfants et acheter une parcelle pour construire sa propre maison. 

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « BARAKA » qui signifie benedictions.
texts.en:
Pascasie N. is a 38-year-old merchant who lives in the urban commune of Buyenzi, in the province of Bujumbura Mairie. For 23 years in Bujumbura City, she has been doing commerce in pagnes (colorful traditional cloth) for women. She has always worked in commerce. She has a 5th grade education and is a widow. She is now on her seventh community loan cycle with the micro-finance institution Turame. She is a mother of five children, who are 16, 14, 10, 8, and 6 years old. All of her children are students. She is asking for a Kiva loan to increase the quantity of pagnes that she purchases for reselling to customers. She hopes to diversify her business in the future by including housewares, such as plates and dishes. With the Turame loan, she hopes to be able to cover her children's schooling costs, as well as to buy a plot of land on which to build her own house. She is a member of the community group "Baraka", which means "blessings".

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing the quantity of cloth she buys for resale to customers

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Dramane D. est une homme marié de 36 et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier Massabla coura de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Dramane D. est un enseignant de profession, qui parallèlement à ce métier, mène des activités d’achat et de vente des animaux (petits ruminants) afin de subvenir à ses besoins. 
Il a appris cette activité auprès de son ami, et la mène  au marché de Bougouni.
Avec une expérience de 6 ans, il maîtrise son activité et est très apprécié. 
Il est à son troisième prêt avec l’institution et tous les prêts précédent ont été correctement remboursé.
Afin d’agrandir son entreprise, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso, pour acheter des animaux sur pieds.
Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni ville et dans les villages environnants.
Avec ce prêt il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000FCFA, qui sera utilisé pour subvenir à ses besoins et investir le reste dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Mr. Dramane D. is a 36 year old married father of three who lives with his wife and children in the Massabla-Coura neighborhood of Bougouni (Third Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. D. is a teacher by profession who in order to meet his needs, also has a business buying and selling animals (small ruminants). He learned this business from a friend, and operates from the Bougouni market. He has 6 years experience in buying and selling animals, and his mastery of the business is much appreciated. This is his third loan with the institution and all the previous loans were repaid on time. In order to grow his business, he decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso to buy live animals. He buys his animals in Bougouni City and in nearby villages. Mr. D. expects to earn 50,000 francs per month income thanks to this loan. The income will be used to meet his needs and he will invest the remainder in his business.

Translated from French by Eileen Jessop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy animals (sheep, goats)

loans.name: Maina

texts.en:
Maina has been operating his mixed farm for the last thirty years in the town of Murang'a in Central Province, Kenya. He produces coffee which he sells to the local market and also earns income from carpentry services he offers to the local people.

Maina is 64 years old and married with nine children who are all adults. His youngest child is currently attending school.

Maina has requested this loan of KES 53,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the income from the sale of its milk will help him in paying school fees for his youngest child.

Maina hopes to expand his dairy farming from indigenous breeds to exotic breeds. He says that Juhudi is doing a commendable job by helping peasant farmers to acquire assets.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mrs. Vanna Yuon Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Vanna Y. is a village bank president who is 48 years old, selected by fourteen members whom all are made up a village bank loan located in Char village in Takeo province. All the members will use portion of the loan for varied ways to support their businesses in the current year. She is a tailor who sews gloves for her customers in which it can earn some money to support her family and she is also a pig breeder. Since her all businesses are going well she wants to increase her face businesses. So to improve those both goals, Mrs. Vanna Y. is applying for a loan to buy more piglets and fabric to sew gloves for her customers. She is widow with two children, one of whom is a seamstress in garment factory, while the other is attending in local school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets

loans.name: Esther

texts.fr:
Madame Esther C. est une femme mariée de 46 ans et mère de 7 enfants qui vit avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier Torakabougou de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Ayant  abandonnée l’école, dès à son jeune âge, elle  commença tôt les activités génératrices de revenus. Pendant des années elle vendait des condiments alimentaires au marché, mais sans succès.
Elle décide alors de faire des achats et  vente de beurre de karité. 
Avec une expérience de plus de 8 ans Madame Esther C. maîtrise son activité. Elle s’approvisionne à Bougouni et dans les villages environnants. 
Elle a appris cette activité auprès de sa mère. 
Elle a fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers une association du quartier. 
Après 4 prêts solidaires, elle vient  au prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursé. 
Ainsi pour renforcer d’avantage son activité, elle continue de collaborer  avec Soro Yiriwaso et compte utiliser ce premier prêt individuel pour acheter du beurre de Karité en grande quantité.
Elle mène cette activité au marché de la ville, dans les marchés hebdomadaires et à la maison.  Sa clientèle est diverse et variée.
Elle compte réaliser,  avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 48 500 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice elle envisage agrandir son entreprise.
texts.en:
Mrs. Esther C. is a married woman, 46 years of age, who is the mother of seven children. She lives with her husband and children in the Torakabougou district of Bougoni (the third administrative republic of Mali). Having left school at a young age, she started working and earning an income early on. For some years she used to sell food condiments at the market, but without much success. She then decided to trade in shea butter. After more than eight years in this line of business, Mrs. Esther C. knows her work well. She stocks up in Bougoni and in the nearby villages. She has learned this business from her mother. She was introduced to Soro Yirwaso thanks to a local association. After four solidarity loans, she has moved on to an individual loan. All previous loans have been properly repaid. In order to strengthen her business further, she continues to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso, and plans to use her first individual loan to purchase large quantities of shea butter. She sells at the town market, at the weekly markets and out of her home. Her customer base is diverse and varied. With this loan, she plans to achieve a monthly income of 48,500 West African Francs. She envisages expanding her business thanks to this income.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing shea butter

loans.name: Dory

texts.en:
Dory D. is from the town of Surallah. She is 37 years old and is married with four school-aged children.

Dory is engaged in rice farming and has been planting and harvesting rice crops for more than eleven years already. She also started growing and fattening hogs for sale. She says she does her best to provide for her family, especially her children's education. Like any mother, she wants to give them a bright future.

Dory joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Dory is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer, such as manure, and feed for her pigs. This loan will be her fourth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees and to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure and feed for her pigs

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste, bread, tomatoes and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to stock bags of onions and Irish potatoes to sell.  Rose is 29 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has 2 children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

loans.use: Stock bags of onions and Irish potatoes to sell

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 21-year-old man from Jabalia, a city in the Gaza Strip. He had to start working immediately after high school to pay for his college tuition fees. Mahmoud worked at electronics shops and saved a good amount of money, which helped him to start his own shop.

Mahmoud sells electronics in the shop in which he appears in the photograph. He sells electronics and accessories, such as calculators, mobile phone accessories, speakers, computer accessories, etc. Mahmoud took a loan from FATEN to expand the items exhibited to include other types, and to increase the amount of goods he sells to respond to demand.

Mahmoud is looking forword to earning his degree and then building his own house.

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Daudi

texts.en:
Daudi is a farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been operating his mixed farm for 20 years and has employed two people from his community.  His main produce is tea which he sells to the  Kenya Tea Development Authority and Finlays Company. He also produces milk which he sells locally. He has established a poultry project and runs a hotel in the same area. 

Daudi is 51 years old. He is married with 7 children between the ages of 3 and 35. Six of the children are currently attending school.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.30,000 to purchase and feed a dairy cow. The extra income earned from this loan will help him pay school fees for his children in school and expand his farming business. He faces the challenge of lnsufficient capital to expand his activities.

In the future, he would like to expand his business, build his own house and educate his children well. He is grateful to Juhudi for giving him a loan and expects to repay it and get another loan.

loans.use: To purchase and feed a dairy cow.

loans.name: Kanyansheko Abamwe, Ibanda Group

texts.en: Three years ago K. Rose started up her banana selling business in Kanyansheko, Ibanda in western Uganda. With this as her only source of livelihood, she has painstakingly managed to make ends meet albeit with some long drawn out seasonal income fluctuations and poor road systems to access bigger markets. With a strong work ethic, the 29 year old married mother of one child has kept her business on a path of consolidated growth. In a month, she makes close to 80,000 Ugandan shillings. Her business has gained ground over these years and her family has benefited. Her business plan of action for the forthcoming future is to be able to sell more bananas to an increasingly expanding market. With this loan, she envisages purchasing manure and fertilizers for the banana plantation in order to improve the output.

loans.use: buying agricultural materials like manure and fertilizers

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en:
Cheng Y., 28, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. Y. charges batteries at home, earning an income of USD 4 per day. Her husband is a mechanic and earns an income of USD 5 per day. 

Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more tools to repair cars and improve her husband’s business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy car repair tools to improve the business

loans.name: Mrs. Kroeun Chou Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fifteen people have been selected by Mrs. Kroeun C. is a village bank president who is 49-year-old located in Char village, Takeo province. All the members will use portion of their loan for different purposes in which it can improve their businesses. Mrs. Kroeun C. and her husband, Mr. Muon Mea, are farmers who rent two-hectare plot land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family and she is also a pig breeder. Through this activity, they support three children, two of whom are weavers, while the other is a student in school. Since her children’ business is going well she wants to expand. So to improve this purpose, Mrs. Kroeun C. is asking for a loan to buy more silk and rest of the loan she hires plow machine to plow her field.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 34 years old. He is married with 2 children ages, 8 and 10. All the children attend school. He is a farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for the last 10 years and has employed one person from his community. His main product is milk which he sells to the tea estate. He is also a cash crop farmer and earns income from the sale of tea at the local market.

His biggest challenge has been the lack of enough animal feed.

Peter has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES.30,000 to purchase and feed a dairy cow. He believes that this dairy cow will increase his source of income through the sale of milk and he will be able to pay school fees for his children in school.

In the future, he would like to improve the quality of his dairy cows through artificial insemination and purchase more dairy cows. He promises to work hard to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy medicine to expand the husband's business.

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben is a member and the secretary of Kapsinendet Chorwa Dairy Group, which is being funded by Juhudi Kilimo. Reuben is 36 years old and married. He has 2 children, ages 3 and 6. His eldest child is currently attending school.

Reuben has been operating his mixed farm for 10 years and has employed four people from his community. His main product is tea, which he sells to Finlay and Kenya Tea Development Authority, and milk, which he sells locally. Apart from farming, he also operates a retail shop in the same area. His biggest challenges in farming have been lack of food and water for his animals.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo, of KES 50,000, to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that with this dairy cow, his income will increase and he will be able to cater for the family's needs and to improve the nutrition of his family.

Reuben would like to improve his dairy farming by acquiring quality dairy cows in the future. He believes that this loan will greatly improve his life.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian G. is currently in the business of selling bags of rice and beans at the store. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of maize flour, pulses and soya beans to sell. Lilian is 37 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a hotel.

loans.use: To stock bags of maize flour, pulses and soya beans to sell.

loans.name: Amouhouè Laurent

texts.fr: A. Amouhouè Laurent est né le 02 Septembre 1972 et vit depuis sa naissance au quartier Agbalilamè à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Laurent est marié à ABLESSI Appoline, une couturière, et est père de trois enfants. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Laurent vit ensemble avec sa famille et assure leurs différentes charges, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Laurent est un couturier, ayant son atelier à son domicile. Laurent désire confectionner un nombre considérable de chemises pour le vendre et augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. Compte tenu du peu de ressources financières dont il dispose, Laurent sollicite un premier prêt de ALIDé, ce qui lui permettra d'atteindre son objectif.
texts.en:
Amouhouè Laurent A. was born on September 2, 1972 and since his birth has lived in the Agbalilamè district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Laurent is married to Appoline ABLESSI, a dressmaker, and is the father of three children, some of whom attend school. Laurent lives together with his family and provides for their various expenses, thanks to the income he obtains from his business. Laurent is a dressmaker with a workshop in his home. He would like to make a large number of shirts to sell and to increase his sales. Given the few financial resources at his disposal, Laurent is requesting a first loan from ALIDé, which will enable him to reach his goal.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and fabric for shirts.

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is 45 years old. He is married and has been blessed with 6 children, all between the ages of 1 and 12. Four of the children are attending school. Samwel is a farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for the past 10 years. His farm produces milk and tea, which he sells locally. His primary challenges have been lack of animal feed and poor transportation network.

Samwel has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo, of KES 50,000, to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that with this loan, he will be able to acquire an additional dairy cow that will increase his income as well as assets that will help him access bigger loans in the future.

In future, Samwel would like to increase the number of his dairy cows to at least five and expand land for planting grass. He hopes to build a dairy unit as well. He is grateful to Juhudi for the support accorded to him.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Luth

texts.en: Luth L., 35, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. L. raises pigs, earning an income of USD 150 per month. Her husband is a construction worker and earns an income of USD 7 per day. L. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase pigs and a plot of farmland to expand the farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. L.'s husband appears in the photograph because L. was not available.

loans.use: To buy pigs.

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie D. is from the town of Surallah. She is 39 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. She is a hog-grower and corn farmer. She has been doing these activities for more than a few years now. It is also how her family earns their income. Her husband does the major farming duties while she helps sell their harvest and raises the hogs. She hopes to have a successful business someday.

Melanie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Melanie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Melanie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.

loans.name: Kipngetich

texts.en:
Kipngetich owns and operates a mixed farm in Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He produces milk, which he sells to the tea estate and tea which he sells to Kenya Tea Development Authority and to Finlays company. He has been farming for the past 7 years and has employed one farm hand. He is also a driver.

Kipngetich is 30 years old, married and blessed with 3 children. The children are between the ages of 3 and 7. All of the children attend school. Kipngetich would like to improve his dairy farming by purchasing four more dairy cows, which will produce at least 20 litres of milk each, on a daily basis. He has requested this loan of KES 50,000 to purchase and insure these dairy cows. He says these dairy cows will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and will also increase his income through the sale of milk. He will, therefore, reduce the cost of buying milk for his family and he will also have increased income that will enable him pay school fees for his children.

Kipngetich says that he would like to stay with Juhudi in the future so that he can be able to purchase another piece of land.

loans.use: To purchase and insure more dairy cows.

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Yen S., 32, is widowed and resides with her three children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. S. sells prepared food, earning an income of USD 3 per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to purchase utensils to start a business of selling food. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to support the studies of her children. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy utensils to start a business of selling food.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow and to improve his poultry farm.

loans.name: Mrs. Phat Mork Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Rung village in Takeo province has eighteen people whom all have been selected Mrs. Phat M. is a village bank president who is 54-year-old. All the members will use portion of their loan for varied ways to support their businesses in the current year. Mrs. Phat M. and her husband, Mr. Loch Chhang, are farmers who owns one point five-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Her problem is that her field is infertile soil and it has a lot of insect. So to improve production, Mrs. Phat M. is seeking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. She is a mother of six children, three of whom are seamstresses in garment factory, while the others are studying in local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Hort

texts.en: Hort Y., 43, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known as the most favorite tourist place in the country. Y. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day. Her husband is a construction worker and earns an income of USD 4 per day. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase water buffaloes to help plow the rice field. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy water buffaloes.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth G. is currently in the business of selling fish, tomatoes and cooking oil at the market and is requesting a loan to stock smoked bush meat (wild game) to sell.  Elizabeth is 40 years old and is married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock smoked bush meat to sell

loans.name: Dionisia

texts.en:
Dionisia C. is from the town of Surallah. She is 62 years old, married and has seven children. While most of her children are adults, she still has her younger ones who go to school and hope to finish college someday. Dionisia owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She also raises ducks. Dionisia has been engaged in her business for over 25 years.

Dionisia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Dionisia has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Dionisia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Dionisia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov Sovannaroth, 24, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the most favorite tourist places in the country. Sovannaroth raises pigs, earning an income of $3 US per day. Her husband is a construction worker and earns an income of  $5 per day. Sovannaroth is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase more pigs to raise, and a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike and pigs

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: Née en 1977 à Abomey dans le Zou au Bénin, G. Bernadette est mariée à DJOSSOU Benoît, un menuisier. Le couple a cinq enfants à charge, dont trois sont leurs enfants. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Bernadette vit avec sa famille depuis cinq ans à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Bernadette vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille, grâce au revenu de son activité. N'ayant jamais fréquenté l'école, Bernadette a appris la coiffure, activité qu'elle exerce depuis trois ans et qui lui permet de faire face à ses charges. Dans le but d'agrandir son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Bernadette sollicite pour une première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1977 in Abomey in the Zou region of Benin, Bernadette G. is married to Benoît Djossou, a carpenter. The couple has five children in their care, three of which are their own. Some of the children are in school. Bernadette has lived with her family for the last five years in Ekpè, in the community of Sèmè-Podji. She helps her husband to pay the family’s expenses, thanks to her business income. Never having gone to school, Bernadette learned hairstyling and has been in the business for the last three years, which helps her to pay her expenses. With the goal of expanding her business and better meeting her clients’ needs, she is requesting a loan for her first time through ALIDé.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hair extensions and hair products.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda E. is from the town of Surallah. She is 49 years old. Erlinda is married and has seven school-aged children. Erlinda owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She also helps her husband maintain their rice farm by keeping it free of weeds and pests. She also sells their harvest in their town's market. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years. 

Erlinda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase livestock feed & also farm supplies. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Erlinda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve her family's living conditions. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: buying livestock feed & farm supplies

loans.name: Mrs. Moun Morn Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Moun M. is a village bank president who was born in 1961, selected by eighteen people who are made up a village bank loan in Rung village, Takeo province. All the members will use portion of their loan for varied purposes to support their businesses. Mrs. Moun M. and her husband, Mr. Chork Kun, is a farmer who own five-hectare plot land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. Her problem is that her field is infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Moun M. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed. According this activity, they support three children whom are attending in local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
50-year-old Susan D. is from the town of Surallah. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. She does farming for a living. She and her husband plant and harvest rice crops. Their harvest is for consumption and sale. She also raises ducks and hopes to acquire additional ducks to grow. She also needs feed to sustain her ducks.

Susan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Susan is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and also feed for the ducks. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Susan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seed, and duck feed

loans.name: Hripsik

texts.en: Hripsik M. is a widow living with her son and daughter. She is a hardworking and enthusiastic woman. Hripsik’s family shares their living space with her sister and mother-in-law. Hripsik has been successfully running a beauty salon since 2009. Both Hripsik’s children help their mother in running the business. To create comfortable conditions and meet her clients' needs Hripsik needs to purchase some necessary beauty salon equipment and install air conditioning.

loans.use: beauty salon equipment and air conditioning installation

loans.name: Rasel

texts.en: Rasel E. has a restaurant and is requesting a loan in order to stock more foodstuffs in it. She is 49 years old and is married to a peasant. She has 5 children in total but only 3 attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more foodstuffs in the restaurant

loans.name: Mrs. Chroeun Pov Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Chroeun P. is a village bank president who has been selected by seventeen people who live in Rung village Takeo province. Each member will use portion of their loan for varied ways to increase their businesses in the current year. Mrs. Chroeun P. is a farmer who owns one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Ret Nou, is a laborer. Now she has some problem because her field is infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Chroeun P. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed and rest of the loan she buys two piglets for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of two children whom all are studying in local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Mrs. Eark Suon Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fifteen people live in Rung village in Takeo province and they are made up a village bank loan. Mrs. Eark S. is a village bank president who was born in 1983. She is a farmer who owns one point five-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family while her husband, Mr. Phoeurn Phen, is a laborer. Now a day, she has some problem because her field is infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Eark S. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and rest of the loan she hires plow machine to plow her field. She is a mother of two children whom all are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Alinyikira Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
38 year old L. Sarah makes 100,000 shillings a week out of her poultry and eggs business in Kasangalabi-Mukono. She says most of her clients are retail buyers. She has been doing this for the last 8 years. With proper planning, proper feeding, and medication, she has ensured stability in her business. Her family of 4 has also been basking in this success. 

She also runs other side businesses: a commercial motorcycle business and a commercial farm. With these she is able to cut both ways in terms of alternating the usage of profits that come from each of her businesses.The proceeds from this loan she says are going to be used to buy more chicken feed and medications for increased output.

loans.use: purchase of chicken feed and medicine

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jerome

texts.en:
Jerome is 41 years old and married with five children who are between 5 and 15 years old.  Jerome is commonly known for his business of sewing different styles of clothes and this is the 20th successful year of his business.  Jerome runs his business from 8 am to 8 pm every day.

Jerome needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With this loan, Jerome will purchase additional sewing machines including an over-sewing machine (serger) which hopefully will allow him to increase the profits in his business.  With these profits, Jerome will start creating some other sources of income so that he can keep building a secure future for his children.

loans.use: To buy additional sewing machines

loans.name: Mrs. Phalla Leng Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eleven people are living I. Khvav village I. Takeo province and they all are made up a village bank loan. Mrs. Phalla L. is a village bank president who is 31-year-old, selected by the other members will use portion of their loan for different purposes. She is a Khmer noodle seller at her home and aside this she is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Now she has some problem because her field is far away from irrigation system and it is infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Phalla L. is seeking for a loan to buy a pump machine and fertilizer. Her husband, Mr. Sok Bam, is a chef and she has four children, three of whom are enrolled I. local public school, while the other is too small to work or study. All the members are shown I. the picture but one of them is blocked.

loans.use: To buy a pump machine and fertilizer

loans.name: Nasreen Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen kosar lives in the city called Borewala, located in Punjab Pakistan. She is the mother of five children who are all getting their education except the youngest one who is three years of age. Her husband is a daily wage labor while she performs her duty of a mid-wife. 

It is not easy for her and her husband to fulfill the basic needs of their family that’s why they both work hard to manage the financial expenses. Nasreen wants to buy some latest medical tools for her work that’s why she has applied for a loan from Asasah.

She is a second year member of Asasah and in the first year she built a good record of repayments and never missed any meetings.  She hopes that this loan will also help her in improving her work.

loans.use: Purchase medical tools

loans.name: Muna

texts.en:
Muna is a 38-year-old mother from Jabalia, a city in the Gaza Strip. She is the mother of one son and three daughters. Muna helps her husband by working in the home accessories store that he owns in the city.

Summer is the wedding season, which means a high demand for home accessories. Muna and her husband decided to take a $2,000 loan from FATEN to purchase more goods to respond to the increasing demand.

Muna and her husband, Yaser, who appears in the picture, hope to have a small weaving factory and produce their own products.

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Andranik

texts.en: Andranik M. is married and has one boy. The couple is expecting their second child soon. The family lives together with Andranik’s mother in Goraiq village, Syunik province. Their main financial resource is cattle breeding and grass mowing and selling.  Andranik’s machinery is very old and often breaks down. With the loan he plans to fix the machinery as well as purchase diesel and cattle food.

loans.use: fixing the old machinery, purchasing diesel and cattle food

loans.name: Mrs. Rin Sao Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Khvav villge, Takeo province has fourteen people who are made up a village bank loan and they all have been selected Mrs. Rin S. is a village bank president who is 1971. Each member will use portion of their loan for different purposes in which it can improve their businesses. Mrs. Rin S. and her husband, Mr. Khnet Chea, are farmers who owns one-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support their family and he is a basket maker. Both of thE. try to work hard but they can earn less income. So to improve production, Mrs. Rin S. is finding for a loan to buy a cow for breeding to start a new business. She is a mother of three children whom all are studying in local public school. Mrs. chanthol Torn is a group guarantor so she is presented in the picture. All the members are shown in the picture but one of thE. is blocked.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Jean Michel

texts.en:
Jean Michel is 28 years and married with three children who are 2, 4 and 8 years old.  Jean Michel makes a living by driving a motorbike and he has been in this business for about three years.  Jean Michel drives from 7 am until late in the evening hours.

Jean Michel needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a. This loan will allow him to purchase another motorbike, which will allow him to create one more job for one of the people in his community and increase the size of his profits.  Jean Michel, through the use of this loan, has hope for a better future for his children.

loans.use: To buy one additional motorbike

loans.name: Umaru

texts.en:
Kirindi-Kayunga is where 38-year-old O. Umaru has been operating his butcher shop for a decade now. With weekly 100,000 shillings profits accruing to his business, he is able to make ends meet reliably. As a result of his hard work and the good rapport he has with the meat suppliers, his business has prospered. Being a responsible married father, he has ensured all his 3 children are in school. 

With this loan, he wants to expand his business by constructing another butcher shop and he also believes he will be able to buy more kilograms of meat as his prospects improve.

loans.use: construction of second butcher shop; purchase of meat

loans.name: Ffena Tugagawale - Mukono Group

texts.en: This 35-year-old man was a business intermediary before he began his shoes sales and grocery business in Kikko, Kame Valley market of Mukono, 5 years ago. Going by J. Muhamadi’s own account, hard work has gotten him this far. It is the reason why his business generates him reliable weekly profits that add up to 130,000 shillings. With the stability and consolidation in his business operations, have also come some good virtues. The upshot has been that he has been able to reliably provide for his family of 4 school-going children, plus his wife. With this loan, Muhamadi wants to buy more shoes for reselling.

loans.use: The purchase of more pairs of shoes for resale

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 54 years old and married with two children who are 18 and 21 years old.  Daniel is commonly known for selling drinks (PRIMUS and MITZIIG) and he has been in this business for about six years.  Daniel opens his shop from 7 am to 9 pm every day.

Daniel is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company hoping that he can increase his profits by expanding his business.  With the use of this loan, Daniel will also start roasting meat to sell to his customer. A large number of his customers have requested this.  Daniel hopes that through the expansion of his business, he will start creating some other sources of income as well creating more jobs for the people in his community.

loans.use: To buy additional drinks to sell

loans.name: Ngam Ntoh

texts.en:
Born in 1944, Ngam Ntoh E. has been having difficulties trying to raise business capital. He is married and has nine children.  He had tried borrowing money from other financial institutions but had problems of repayment due to high interest rates. He joined GHAPE in 2007. He has taken and repaid loans two times and he had no repayment problem.  He faces difficulties taking care of his family, especially when they are sick
The buy and sell of basic commodities is a very profitable trade in his community so he decided to obtain a loan from GHAPE in order to carry out this trade. He had received and repaid loans two times from GHAPE.

He knows he will succeed in the trade because he has been doing this trade for a very long time and has so many customers. He plans to expand in his trade by purchasing three bags of rice, three cartons of savon (soap), four cartons of tine tomatoes and five bags of salt. With profit from this business, he plans to carry out repairs on his uncompleted house, pay tuition fees and buy school needs for his children.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase rice, soap, tomatoes, salt and groundnuts.

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
A. Aziza is a hardworking and responsible woman. Twelve years ago she decided to start her own business to provide for her family. Ever since she has been selling clothes and shoes for women. This activity has also permitted her to make time available to be with her children. To increase her sales, Aziza requests a loan of $1000 US, which she will use to buy merchandise that is on sale; she will then resell it at a special price to her customers. This will allow her to grow her customer base. You can be an important enabler of Aziza's accomplishments. She needs your help to grow her business and improve the quality of living of her family. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Clothing and shoe store inventory

loans.name: Tosam Nkwain

texts.en:
Tosam Nkwain E. is married and has one child. Health problems have rendered him not strong enough to cultivate crops, which is the main economic activity in his community. As a result, he has resorted to retail trade, which is less strenuous. Due to inadequate capital, he could not raise enough revenue to meet the needs of his family. Motivated by other GHAPE members in his community, he joined the program in 2007 and has received and repaid loans two times with no repayment problems. He now intends to obtain his third loan, which will be used for the purchase of bread, rice, salt and drinks.
  
The profit he gets from the loans will be used to complete his house and cater to his child’s education. His community will benefit from this in that there will be more locally made bread from the urban city of Bamenda available and the people won't have to go far to buy it. 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase bread, salt, rice and drinks

loans.name: Khawla

texts.en:
Khawla B. runs a small family business with her husband. They have owned a small women's clothing shop for two years. Khawla is thinking of improving the shop by adding stands and equipment to exhibit the clothes in order to have a better clothing display for their customers.

Khawla took a $1,500 loan from FATEN to improve her shop. She would like to take a another one after she repays the current one so she can have a specialized women's shop in the future.

In the photograph, Khawla's stands next to women's clothes that she sells in her shop.

loans.use: Purchase shop accessories

loans.name: Kuisunoy

texts.en:
A. Kuisunoy is a widow and has a daughter. Her clothing sales business has been a valuable source of income for her and her family over the past 3 years that she’s been in business. In a typical month Kuisunoy makes about $200-$300 in profit from the business. Kuisunoy is a hard-working, polite and communicative entrepreneur. She has an attitude of service and loves being able to help men with their clothing needs. Kuisunoy has requested a loan of $1000 USD to purchase new inventory. This loan will help her to continue developing her business and provide a good income for her family.

loans.use: Purchasing new summer clothing for women

loans.name: Shavkat

texts.en:
Cattle are raised in order to be butchered, to obtain derived products, as well as to be used for agricultural tasks. Shavkat has been dedicated to cattle farming for 5 years. He started this business as a young man, with his father's support. He is presently the father of 4 children of all ages. He makes a great effort in order to meet the needs of the children in his charge and to bring sustenance to his humble home. His greatest need now is to buy young cattle for expanding his business. For this reason, Shavkat turned to IMON International, in order to obtain loans that will allow him to purchase these animals and make his business advance.

loans.use: Purchasing cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Benjamin F.

texts.en: Benjamin F. M. is a licensed dealer in patient medicines and also a student of Njala University Kowama campus Bo. Benjamin had been a leader of one of our successful solidarity groups. His group has a good credit history. He is married with four children. Three of his children are in primary school. His wife assists him greatly to sell at the shop when he is in college. Benjamin needs a loan to buy more stocks of medicines for his pharmacy. He intends to use the proceeds from this loan to pay his college fees and feed his family.

loans.use: pharmacy inventory

loans.name: Beng Ntoh

texts.en:
Born in 1968, Beng Ntoh L. is married and has two children. He was encouraged to become a GHAPE member in 2007 as he was finding it too difficult to take care of his family and he was looking for business capital. Also, he has been having a lot of marital problems with his wife. This has made him feel sad all the time but he is appreciative of the fact that he is alive. His desire is to give his children love and education. He states that he feels better each time he provides something for his children.

Since 2007, he has taken and repaid two loans and has proven himself to be very hardworking. His inability to get investment capital, which could constantly generate income for him to meet his children’s needs, is what motivated him to obtain a loan from GHAPE.

Given a loan, he plans to buy palm nuts, groundnuts and farm tools for sale. These articles are in high demand in his area. He knows this business will succeed because he is located at a good business site. He plans to use the profits generated to sponsor his children in school and to cater for the basic needs of his family. 

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy palm nuts, groundnuts and farm tools

loans.name: Bashorat

texts.en:
A. Bashorat is a widow with three children. She sells kid’s clothing in the central market of Dushanbe. She has a wide variety of merchandise combined with reasonable prices. Bashorat has been in this trade for 6 years. She is trying to do everything she can to provide for the wellbeing of her family. That is why she wants to continue expanding her business and growing her trade by increasing the number of her vending locations. Bashorat is requesting a loan of $1300 US to sustain her business and help ensure it continues to provide enough income to live on.

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for increasing stock

loans.name: Shabirkul

texts.en:
Shabirkul D. lives in Chimkent village in the north of Kyrgyzstan. She is 56 years old, married and has 7 children. One of them is of school age and the others are grown up. After graduating from Trade College in the capital city, Shabirkul worked in the trade sector for many years. Her colleagues characterized her as a very diligent and responsible person.   

After the breakdown of the Soviet Union, Shabirkul and her family started their own business of cultivating kidney beans, wheat and potatoes. Using the small amount of 3,000 Kyrgyz soms to purchase and plant seeds, Shabirkul and her family worked hard to get a good harvest. 

Being a persistent person, Shabirkul organized a farmers’ group named “Fruitful Land” and applied for a group loan of 20,000 Kyrgyz soms. She bought a milk cow and fodder for her cattle. After that, Shabirkul applied for an individual loan of another 20,000 Kyrgyz Soms, which she used to cultivate beans and potatoes. Shabirkul used her loans as intended and repaid them without any delays. 

All these activities allowed Shabirkul to give a good dowry to her daughter, hold her son’s wedding and renovate her house. In 2009, life put Shabirkul through a severe test: her husband had a stroke and died. However, Shabirkul braced herself to make her children’s life stable.  

Shabirkul is applying for a loan of 25,000 Kyrgyz soms to purchase fertilizer to cultivate her plot of land with wheat, kidney beans and potatoes. With the revenues from the loan, she plans to broaden her business by purchasing cattle and building a barn.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Kiva borrowers benefit from a 5% discount on the interest rate if they pay back without delay.

Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Henrik

texts.en:
Henrik H. is 58 years old; he lives in Tsovaghugh village, Sevan area. Henrik is married and has a son who is a student. 

Henrik has a higher education: his specialty is mechanical engineering. Now he works at Gegharkunik marz Regional Administration as an expert. At the same time Henrik engages in farming; in his farm he has: cows and calves, pigs, chickens and 16 beehives. Henrik’s wife helps him in farming and thus they support their family and pay for their son’s education. 

Henrik seeks a 1,000,000 AMD loan which he will spend on repairing his beehives and buying wax paper.

loans.use: repairing beehives and buying wax paper

loans.name: Kholik

texts.en:
Kholik N. is 48 years old, married, and has 4 children. Thanks to his efforts to get ahead and his positive attitude in the community he is now a well known and appreciated merchant in his area. Previously Kholik had been a farm hand, working in the fields for different people, and with his hard work he was able to purchase land and cultivate vegetables such as potatoes, onions, carrots, etc. His wife sells his harvest at the market and during their activity in this kind of business his products have become very popular among the buyers. 

Now Kholik requests a loan so he will be better able to serve his customers and differentiate himself from the competition. He will use the loan for purchasing seeds, fertilizer, and cattle. He only wants to continue growing his business and to be able to improve the quality of life for his family. With your help Kholik can get ahead.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds, fertilizer, and cattle

loans.name: Wandum

texts.en:
Born in 1986, Wandum M. is a single mother of two children. She has been very hardworking from the day she joined GHAPE. She explained how good it is for a woman to work for herself and to care for the children. Her desire is to work for her children’s education and to pay for their apprenticeships. She joined GHAPE in 2007 as she was unable to get investment capital which would enable her to increase her income to meet her family's needs. Since then, she has successfully received and repaid two loans.

With this third loan she plans to buy five tons of corn, two tons of beans and to pay workers who will work in her farm. This investment will help her community as she will retail her goods to the public.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy corn, seedlings and to pay laborers

loans.name: Nasiba

texts.en:
S. Nasiba is 36 years old. She is married and has three children. She is a very active woman. Eight years ago Nasiba started the business of raising sheep. She sells them after fattening at the local market, usually to local restaurants. With the income she generates she provides a better quality of life for her children, who are playing the main role in her life. 

Despite recent success, since her business is still quite small, and it doesn't generate enough income for the whole family. Nasiba would like to request some loan to expand her business, increase family income and will use the profit generate from the business to repay the loan on time. With this purpose she is asking for a loan of $3000 USD in order to buy more young sheep to later sell when they are fully grown. The well being of Nasiba’s family and her business are in your hands. 
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing small sheep in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family

loans.name: Malika

texts.en:
U. Malika is a bread maker. She has her own bakery in her house. With experience has come success in this business. She’s been able to succeed by diversifying her products. Malika makes white bread, sweet bread, buns and pastries. Malika’s immediate need is to acquire basic ingredients to continue baking bread. This is why she’s looking for support from IMON International, to obtain credit that will allow her to buy the ingredients she needs to continue her bakery business at home. With your support, you can improve the quality of life for Malika and her family and help her business grow and prosper.

loans.use: Purchase flour wholesale for baking the national bread “lepeshka”.

loans.name: Makhsud

texts.en:
Z. Makhsud is 34 years old, married, and has three children. Makhsud has been a farmer since he was very young. He plants potatoes and other vegetables and also raises cattle at his house. Makhsud alternates the crops so that while one is growing the other is ready to be cleaned and prepared, until finally be begins to plant potatoes again. Growing potatoes is very profitable because there are certain seasons when prices are higher and farmers have the opportunity to increase their capital. Currently Makhsud needs funds for growing his crops and purchasing young cattle, and for that reason he applied to IMON International with the request of 13000 Somoni loan. He will spend this loan for buying seeds, fertilizer and young cattle. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of seeds, fertilizer and young cattle

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en: Hanan is a thirty-eight-year-old widow from Lebanon.  In order to raise her six orphans, Hanan developed her skills in handcrafts and made her own business since 2004. She works hard to improve her business and a stable business, for her children's sake, making sure they will have a secure future. Hanan requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to improve her work and buy the necessary merchandise for such industry. Hanan believes that the quality of her work is what keeps her strong in the market. Her hope is to help her children have their own strong businesses.

loans.use: To improve her work, and buy the necessary merchandise for handicrafts

loans.name: Tagaymurod

texts.ru: Шарбатов Тагаймурод проживает в районе Фархор. Возраст, 59 лет. Женат, имеет 9 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Тагаймурод имеет средне - специальное образование, продавец. Более 8 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Продает сельскохозяйственные продукты в оптом. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Tagaymurod S. lives in Farkhor. He is 59 years old, married, and has nine children. His wife is a housewife. Tagaymurod has a vocational education in sales. He has been working in sales at the market for more than eight years. He sells agricultural products wholesale. He is taking out a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing sales

loans.name: Ami
